questions.question: How does SMA* account for the f value of a forgotten node?

answers.b: The value is noted down in a separate list.
answers.c: The value is backed up to the parent.
answers.d: The value is reset to infinity.

questions.question: When does SMA* regenerate a subtree?

answers.a: When the algorithm reaches its maximum iteration limit and requires a reset
answers.b: When the node is encountered again
answers.c: When all other paths have been shown to look worse than the forgotten path

questions.question: In this implementation of the algorithm, can there be multiple f values for the same node in the frontier?

explanations.a: Try to construct an example where this is true.

questions.question: Which statement is true about SMA* search and Uniform Cost Search (UCS)?

answers.a: Both are informed search, and UCS is ordered by h value
answers.b: Both are uninformed search, and UCS is ordered by g value
answers.c: UCS is uninformed search, and SMA* is informed search ordered by g value
answers.d: UCS is uninformed search, and SMA* is informed search ordered by f value

explanations.a: There is no heuristic in UCS.
explanations.c: SMA* is ordered by f value.

questions.question: What is the tradeoff in SMA* ?

answers.a: Memory limitations making the computation time longer
answers.b: Computation time making the memory size longer
answers.c: Memory limitations making the computation time shorter
answers.d: Computation time making the memory size shorter

questions.question: What happens if a node is at max depth?

answers.a: If its not a goal node, its f cost is set to infinity and it is added.
answers.b: If its a goal node, it is added.
